relatedDocuments.title: Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings, 2013 Provisional Results
relatedDocuments.summary: The Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE) is based on a 1% sample of employee jobs. This is drawn from HM Revenue and Customs Pay As You Earn (PAYE) records. This bulletin contains provisional results from the 2013 survey and revised results from the 2012 survey.

relatedDocuments.title: UK Labour Market, July 2014
relatedDocuments.summary: Labour market statistics (including employment, unemployment and economic inactivity) for the United Kingdom.

title: Average weekly hours worked – part time

breadcrumb.title: Home
breadcrumb.summary: The UK's largest independent producer of official statistics and the recognised national statistical institute of the UK.

breadcrumb.title: Employment and Labour market
breadcrumb.summary: Labour market statistics tell us about people in and out of work. They cover a wide range of areas, such as: employment, unemployment, participation in the labour force, types of work, earnings, benefits, working patterns and workplace disputes.

breadcrumb.title: People in work
breadcrumb.summary: People in work are those classed as in employment. Figures here focus on employment rates, hours of work, full and part time workers and earnings.

breadcrumb.title: Earnings and working hours
breadcrumb.summary: Earnings are the reward for work and they can be paid on a regular basis or as bonus pay. Total pay combines both regular and bonus pay. The Office for National Statistics reports the level and growth rate of average weekly total, regular and bonus pay. Working hours are given as the average weekly hours worked by full-time and part-time workers.
